title: BillSplitterMDS
text:
2025-26 DSCI-524 Group 14 - A Python package to help groups split trip bills fairly among participants.
  


When a group of people travel together, different people often pay for different expenses throughout the trip. At the end, it can be complicated to figure out how much each person actually owes and how money should be transferred to settle all debts fairly.
BillSplitterMDS simplifies this process by:

Reading expense data from a CSV file
Validating the data (checking tax/tip ranges, required columns)
Calculating how much each person should pay based on shared items
Calculating how much each person actually paid
Computing the optimal transfers needed to balance everyone’s contributions




Install from TestPyPI:
pip install -i https://test.pypi.org/simple/ --extra-index-url https://pypi.org/simple/ billsplittermds
Or install from source:
git clone https://github.com/UBC-MDS/BillSplitterMDS.git
cd BillSplitterMDS
pip install -e .



Here’s a complete example showing how to use all four functions in the package.


First, let’s create a sample CSV file with trip expenses:

import pandas as pd

# Create sample trip expense data
data = {
    'payer': ['Amy', 'Sam', 'Ben', 'Amy'],
    'item_name': ['Pasta Dinner', 'Taxi to Airport', 'Hotel Room', 'Drinks'],
    'item_price': [18.0, 40.0, 200.0, 30.0],
    'shared_by': ['Amy', 'Amy;Sam;Ben', 'Amy;Ben', 'Amy;Sam;Ben'],
    'tax_pct': [0.08, 0.08, 0.10, 0.08],
    'tip_pct': [0.15, 0.10, 0.00, 0.18]
}

# Save to CSV
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
df.to_csv('trip_expenses.csv', index=False)
print("Sample CSV created:")
print(df.to_string(index=False))

Sample CSV created:
payer       item_name  item_price   shared_by  tax_pct  tip_pct
  Amy    Pasta Dinner        18.0         Amy     0.08     0.15
  Sam Taxi to Airport        40.0 Amy;Sam;Ben     0.08     0.10
  Ben      Hotel Room       200.0     Amy;Ben     0.10     0.00
  Amy          Drinks        30.0 Amy;Sam;Ben     0.08     0.18





Use load_validate_data() to read the CSV and validate that all values are within acceptable ranges:

from billsplittermds import load_validate_data

# Load and validate the expense data
valid_df = load_validate_data('trip_expenses.csv')
print("Data loaded and validated successfully!")
print(f"  - {len(valid_df)} expense records")
print(f"  - Tax range: {valid_df['tax_pct'].min():.0%} to {valid_df['tax_pct'].max():.0%}")
print(f"  - Tip range: {valid_df['tip_pct'].min():.0%} to {valid_df['tip_pct'].max():.0%}")

Data loaded and validated successfully!
  - 4 expense records
  - Tax range: 8% to 10%
  - Tip range: 0% to 18%





Use split_by_item() to calculate each person’s fair share based on which items they consumed:

from billsplittermds import split_by_item

# Calculate what each person should pay
should_pay = split_by_item(valid_df)
print("\nWhat each person SHOULD pay (based on items consumed):")
print(should_pay.to_string(index=False))
print(f"\nTotal: ${should_pay['should_pay'].sum():.2f}")


What each person SHOULD pay (based on items consumed):
name  should_pay
 Ben  138.333333
 Sam   28.333333
 Amy  160.473333

Total: $327.14





Use individual_total_payments() to sum up what each person actually spent:

from billsplittermds import individual_total_payments

# Calculate what each person actually paid
actually_paid = individual_total_payments(valid_df)
print("\nWhat each person ACTUALLY paid (who paid the bills):")
print(actually_paid.to_string(index=False))
print(f"\nTotal: ${actually_paid['actually_paid'].sum():.2f}")


What each person ACTUALLY paid (who paid the bills):
name  actually_paid
 Amy          59.94
 Ben         220.00
 Sam          47.20

Total: $327.14





Use amount_to_transfer() to determine who owes money to whom:

from billsplittermds import amount_to_transfer

# Calculate the transfers needed to settle up
transfers = amount_to_transfer(should_pay, actually_paid)
print("\nTransfers needed to settle all debts:")
if len(transfers) == 0:
    print("  No transfers needed - everyone is settled!")
else:
    for _, row in transfers.iterrows():
        print(f"  {row['sender']} -> {row['receiver']}: ${row['amount']:.2f}")


Transfers needed to settle all debts:
  Amy -> Ben: $81.67
  Amy -> Sam: $18.87






# Clean up the sample file
import os
os.remove('trip_expenses.csv')
print("\nDemo complete! Sample file cleaned up.")


Demo complete! Sample file cleaned up.






Your CSV file must have these columns:



Column
Description
Valid Range
Example




payer
Name of person who paid
Any string
Amy


item_name
Description of expense
Any string
Pasta


item_price
Price before tax/tip
>= 0
18.00


shared_by
Names separated by semicolons
Any string
Amy;Ben


tax_pct
Tax as decimal
0.05 to 0.15
0.08


tip_pct
Tip as decimal
0.00 to 0.50
0.15

This Code of Conduct applies both within project spaces and in public spaces when an individual is representing the project or its community. title: Development Tools & Practices Reflection
text:
This page discusses the tools, GitHub infrastructure, and organizational practices used in developing BillSplitterMDS, along with recommendations for scaling projects.











Tool
Purpose




Git
Distributed version control for tracking changes


GitHub
Repository hosting, issue tracking, project boards, code review


GitHub Actions
CI/CD automation for testing, linting, and deployment









Tool
Purpose




pytest
Unit testing framework for Python


pytest-cov
Code coverage measurement


Codecov
Coverage tracking and reporting service


ruff
Fast Python linter for code style checking













Tool
Purpose




Quarto
Scientific and technical publishing system


quartodoc
Auto-generate API documentation from Python docstrings


GitHub Pages
Free hosting for documentation website













Tool
Purpose




hatchling
Modern Python build backend


twine
Package upload to PyPI/TestPyPI


TestPyPI
Testing package distribution before production release









For most development work, we followed GitHub Flow:

Create feature branch from main
Make changes and commit with meaningful messages
Open pull request for code review
Address feedback from team members
Merge to main after approval

This workflow is simple and effective for continuous deployment.



For coordinated feature sets requiring multiple PRs, we used Git Flow:

Create development branch from main
Create feature branches from development
Merge features into development via reviewed PRs
Final merge of development into main

This provides a staging area to coordinate related changes before release.




Every PR requires at least one reviewer
Use GitHub’s review features (comments, suggestions, approvals)
Check that CI passes before merging
Squash commits for cleaner history when appropriate





Our automated pipeline includes:
Push/PR to main
    │
    ├── Run tests (pytest)
    │
    ├── Check code style (ruff)
    │
    ├── Measure coverage (pytest-cov)
    │
    └── Upload coverage (Codecov)

Release published
    │
    ├── Build package
    │
    └── Deploy to TestPyPI



If scaling this or another project, we recommend:



Add integration tests for end-to-end workflows
Add property-based testing with Hypothesis
Set minimum coverage thresholds (e.g., 80%)





Add type hints to all functions
Use mypy for static type checking
Include type checking in CI pipeline





Enable Dependabot for dependency updates
Add secret scanning
Use signed commits





Add more tutorials and use-case examples
Include contribution guidelines for new developers
Add changelog automation





Deploy to production PyPI (not just TestPyPI)
Consider Docker containers for reproducibility
Add staging environment for testing releases





Use GitHub Projects for sprint planning
Automate issue triage with labels
Set up milestone tracking and burndown charts








Early CI/CD setup: Catching issues early saved debugging time
Clear docstrings: Made quartodoc documentation generation smooth
GitHub Issues: Helped track work and communicate asynchronously
Code review: Improved code quality and shared knowledge





Coordinating changes: Multiple people editing same files required communication
Documentation rendering: Quarto/quartodoc setup had learning curve
Version management: Keeping pyproject.toml and git tags in sync





Invest time in tooling setup early - it pays dividends
Write tests as you code, not after
Document decisions in issues for future reference
Use meaningful commit messages for easier debugging





The combination of GitHub Actions, pytest, ruff, and quartodoc provided a robust development infrastructure for BillSplitterMDS. These tools enabled automated quality checks, consistent code style, and professional documentation with minimal manual effort.
For future projects, we would maintain this toolset while adding type checking and expanding test coverage earlier in development.

title: Development Tools & Practices Reflection
text:
Early CI/CD setup: Catching issues early saved debugging time
Clear docstrings: Made quartodoc documentation generation smooth
GitHub Issues: Helped track work and communicate asynchronously
Code review: Improved code quality and shared knowledge





Coordinating changes: Multiple people editing same files required communication
Documentation rendering: Quarto/quartodoc setup had learning curve
Version management: Keeping pyproject.toml and git tags in sync





Invest time in tooling setup early - it pays dividends
Write tests as you code, not after
Document decisions in issues for future reference
Use meaningful commit messages for easier debugging

title: Development Tools & Practices Reflection
text:
The combination of GitHub Actions, pytest, ruff, and quartodoc provided a robust development infrastructure for BillSplitterMDS. These tools enabled automated quality checks, consistent code style, and professional documentation with minimal manual effort.
For future projects, we would maintain this toolset while adding type checking and expanding test coverage earlier in development.

title: Contributing to BillSplitterMDS
text:
We welcome contributions to the BillSplitterMDS project! This document outlines our collaboration strategy and how to contribute.


We follow GitHub Flow for our development workflow:

Create a branch from main for your work
Make commits to your branch
Open a Pull Request when ready for review
Discuss and review the code
Merge to main after approval







Python 3.9 or higher
Git





Fork and clone the repository:
git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/BillSplitterMDS.git
cd BillSplitterMDS
Install the package in development mode:
pip install -e ".[dev]"
Run tests to verify setup:
pytest







If you find a bug, please open an issue with: - A clear title and description - Steps to reproduce the bug - Expected vs actual behavior - Your environment (Python version, OS)



Feature suggestions are welcome! Please open an issue with: - A clear description of the feature - Why it would be useful - Any implementation ideas you have




Create a new branch:
git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name
Make your changes and write tests
Run the test suite:
pytest
Commit your changes with a descriptive message:
git commit -m "Add feature: description of changes"
Push to your fork:
git push origin feature/your-feature-name
Open a Pull Request





Provide a clear description of the changes
Link any related issues
Ensure all tests pass
Request review from at least one team member
Address review feedback promptly






Follow PEP 8 style guidelines
Write docstrings for all public functions (NumPy style)
Keep functions focused and modular




This contributing guide is adapted from general open-source best practices and GitHub Flow guidelines.

title: amount_to_transfer
text:
amount_to_transfer
Module for calculating money transfers to settle debts.





Name
Description




amount_to_transfer
Compute money transfers required to settle individual balances.





amount_to_transfer.amount_to_transfer(should_pay_df, actually_paid_df)
Compute money transfers required to settle individual balances.
This function takes the outputs of ‘split_by_item’ and ‘individual_total_payments’ functions and determines how much money should be transferred between individuals, so that each person’s final spending equals the amount they should have paid.











Name
Type
Description
Default




should_pay_df
pandas.DataFrame
Dataframe containing the amount each individual should pay according to splitting. Typically the output of ‘split_by_item’.
required


actually_paid_df
pandas.DataFrame
Dataframe containing the amount each individual actually paid. Typically the output of ‘individual_total_payments’.
required














Name
Type
Description




result_df
pandas.DataFrame
A dataframe describing the required transfers with the following columns: - ‘sender’ : name of the person who should send money - ‘receiver’ : name of the person who should receive money - ‘amount’ : amount of money to be transferred














Name
Type
Description





ValueError
If required columns are missing from input dataframes.






>>> should_pay_df
    name   should_pay
0   Leo     30.0
1   Ana     30.0
2   Mia     30.0
>>> actually_paid_df
    name   actually_paid
0   Leo     50.0
1   Ana     40.0
2   Mia     0.0
>>> amount_to_transfer(should_pay_df, actually_paid_df)
    sender  receiver    amount
0   Mia     Leo         20.0
1   Mia     Ana         10.0
